questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with asymptomatic skin lesions on the upper back as in the image. Which of the following is given for the treatment?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows the lesions of Pityriasis versicolor, which is treated using antifungal agents like ketoconazole. Pityriasis versicolor is caused by Malassezia, a dimorphic lipophilic fungus, also known as Pityrosporum. It is a component of normal skin flora.

Griseofulvin (Option B)is used primarily for dermatophyte infections of skin, nails, and hair, like tinea capitis, but not for P. versicolor.

Betamethasone (Option D)is a corticosteroid and is not used for the treatment of P. versicolor as it may worsen the condition.

questions.text: The histopathology of Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by
questions.solution: Chromoblastomycosis histology - In the foreign-body granuloma, - giant cells engulfed with groups of fungal cells may be seen. They are chestnut or golden brown, and therefore can be easily distinguished in the infiltrate. The cells characteristically divide into several planes of division by thick septa and are termedmuriform or sclerotic cells/copper penny bodies

questions.text: In thick skin, such as the palms and soles, the translucent appearance of the stratum lucidum is due to the presence of which substance?
questions.solution:
The translucent appearance of the stratum lucidum is due to the substance eleidin.

  • Stratum lucidum is a translucent layer of the epidermis seen only in thick skin (palms and soles), located between the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.
  • The cells here are anucleate and filled with eleidin, a refractile protein that contributes to the translucent appearance of this layer.
  • Eleidin is derived from keratohyalin granules of the stratum granulosum.

Keratohyalin (Option A): Found in the stratum granulosum, not stratum lucidum; it's a precursor of profilaggrin, not responsible for translucency.

Melanin (Option B): A dark pigment located in basal keratinocytes and melanocytes; it provides skin colour, not translucency.

Tonofibrils (Option D): Bundles of keratin filaments in keratinocytes, mainly in stratum spinosum; they provide mechanical strength, not a translucent appearance.

questions.text: The most abundant form of collagen present in dermis is
questions.solution:
• Dermis forms a major part of the skin and is highly vascular, primarily consisting of the extracellular matrix of connective tissue.
  • Type I collagen is the predominant type of collagen present in the dermis, approximately 80% of the total collagen

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a complaint of sudden, marked hair loss that began two weeks ago. On examination, there is diffuse hair thinning with broken hairs of varying lengths, but the scalp appears normal. She recently started a new medication as part of treatment for a systemic illness. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
The rapid onset of diffuse hair loss within 1-3 weeks, especially with broken hairs, is classic for Anagen Effluvium, a form of non-scarring alopecia, most often triggered by cytotoxic agents such as doxorubicin. These drugs damage rapidly proliferating hair matrix cells, leading to fragile, dystrophic anagen hairs.

In contrast, heparin, propranolol, and isotretinoin are known to cause Telogen Effluvium, which has a delayed onset (~3 months after exposure) due to premature shift of follicles from anagen to telogen phase.

choices.text: Androgens are related to the pathogenesis
Obesity and smoking are the 2 main factors associated with it
IL-17 inhibitors like secukinumab can be used in treatment
It is a disease of the sebaceous glands

questions.text: A patient presents recurrent abscesses with tract formation and scars in the groin region. Which is the incorrect statement regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), also called acne inversus, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition with lesions including deep-seated nodules and abscesses, draining tracts, and fibrotic scars.

These lesions most commonly occur in intertriginous areas and areas rich in apocrine glands - axillary, groin, perianal, perineal, and inframammary locations.

Environmental and behavioral factors also contribute - Obesity, Smoking, Metabolic syndrome and hormonal changes leading to relative androgen excess, all of which are associated with HS.

questions.text: The condition seen in the illustration is:
questions.solution:
• The clinical image shows rhinophyma, a subtype of phymatous rosacea, which is a chronic inflammatory condition, characterized by progressive hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands and connective tissue of the nose.
  • Rhinophyma is the most common site of phyma, though phymatous changes can also involve:
  • Chin (gnatophyma)
  • Ears (otophyma)
  • Forehead (metophyma)
  • Eyelids (blepharophyma)

Rhinophymoma:

Epidemiology:

  • Most often seen in white men between the 5th and 7th decades.
  • Rare in women and uncommon in Asian and African populations.

Clinical Features:

  • May follow inflammatory lesions or appear de novo.
  • Characterized by:
  • Thickened skin
  • Prominent follicular openings
  • Tortuous telangiectasias
  • Peau d'orange appearance
  • Erythematous papules/pustules
  • Oily skin and malodor with manipulation
  • In advanced cases, soft tissue distortion with bulbous nasal protuberances

Treatment:

  • Surgical debridement
  • CO2 laser

Explanation of Other Options:

Acne vulgaris (Option B): Typically involves comedones, cysts, and pustules. It lacks skin thickening or sebaceous gland hypertrophy as seen in rhinophyma.

Affects the scalp (Option C): Rhinophyma affects the nose, not the scalp.

Dermatofibroma (Option D): A benign fibrous skin nodule, unrelated to rosacea or sebaceous gland proliferation.

questions.text: The most common type of Leprosy in India is
questions.solution:
Borderline Tuberculoid s is the most frequently seen form of leprosy in India. It lies on the tuberculoid side of the Ridley-Jopling spectrum and is characterized by:

  • Few to several well-demarcated hypopigmented skin lesions
  • Asymmetric peripheral nerve involvement
  • Partial cell-mediated immunity - enough to limit bacterial proliferation, but not enough for complete clearance
  • Negative or weakly positive slit-skin smears
  • Pseudopodia like extensions

It is common in India due to the overall moderate immune response found in most individuals exposed to Mycobacterium leprae in endemic settings.

The upper arm of an Indian man showing a typical dry, hairless, hypopigmented plaque with a scaly, red edge. Such Lesions are usually anaesthetic.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Tuberculoid Leprosy (Option A):

This form shows very strong cell-mediated immunity with typically one or two lesions and often a positive lepromin test.

Incorrect because it is less common than borderline tuberculoid in the population, though it may be seen in individuals with very robust immune responses.

Borderline Lepromatous (Option C):

This form is closer to the lepromatous pole and presents with more numerous and less defined lesions. It reflects a lower cell-mediated immunity.

Incorrect because it is less prevalent in India compared to borderline tuberculoid.

Lepromatous Leprosy (Option D):

This form occurs in patients with poor cell-mediated immunity. It shows widespread, symmetric lesions and a high bacillary load.

Incorrect because although common, it is not as frequent as borderline tuberculoid in India.

questions.text: A 24 year old male patient presents with a single hypopigmented anesthetic patch on the arm. The clinician suspects early leprosy. During sensory testing, which modality should be examined first, as it is typically the earliest to be lost?
questions.solution:
• The earliest sensation to be lost in leprosy is temperature discrimination. Mycobacterium leprae affects small, unmyelinated or thinly myelinated sensory fibers early.These fibers transmit Temperature,
  • It begins with inability to differentiate between hot and cold.Next is pain, followed by fine touch and deep touch.

choices.text: 5% permethrin cream applied twice each day for 3 weeks
5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 8 to 14 hours
1% permethrin cream applied once each day for a week
5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 5 hours

questions.text: A 1-year-old infant presents to the clinic with itchy, exudative skin lesions as shown below. There is a positive family history of scabies. Which medication should be prescribed, and how should it be administered?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and image showing vesiculopapular lesions on the foot, especially in an infant with intense itching and a positive family history of scabies, are classic for infantile scabies. The lesions are typical of burrows and papules seen on the soles, palms, and face in infants, which are less commonly involved in adults. 5% permethrin cream is the first-line treatment and is safe for infants older than 2 months. It must be applied from head to toe, including the scalp and face, and left on for 8-14 hours before washing off. In addition, all household contacts should be treated simultaneously, even if asymptomatic, to eliminate the infestation and prevent reinfestation due to close contact.

For adults, 5% permethrin is also the treatment of choice, but it is applied from the neck down and similarly washed off after 8-14 hours. A repeat application after 7 days is recommended in both cases.

Explanation of other options:

5% permethrin cream applied twice each day for 3 weeks (Option A): Overtreatment, increases risk of irritation and is not recommended.

1% permethrin cream applied once each day for a week (Option C): Incorrect strength-used for head lice, not effective against scabies.

5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 5 hours (Option D): Insufficient contact time - 8 to 14 hours is required for full effectiveness.

Key Takeaways:

  • Vesiculopapular lesions on soles and scalp suggest infantile scabies.
  • Permethrin 5% is the treatment of choice in both infants and adults.
  • All close contacts must be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfestation.

questions.text: A patient presents with asymptomatic rash on the body along with palmoplantar lesions as shown. What can be seen during genital examination ?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of the patient - asymptomatic rash and coppery brown palmoplantar lesions point to diagnosis of Secondary syphilis.

Genital examination in such a patient can show presence of condyloma lata. These are highly infectious, flat-topped, well-demarcated hypertrophic papules or plaques, which often present in intertriginous areas, such as the genitals and anus. CL are usually diagnosed by their characteristic physical appearance confirmed by darkfield microscopy and/or skin biopsy along with serological tests.

Other options

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady, wife of a truck driver, presents with a painless ulcer on her cervix. On examination of the genitalia, there is a 1x1cm beefy red ulcer on the cervix that bleeds on touch. Tissue sample findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient has lesions of granuloma inguinale. A painless beefy red ulcer that bleeds on touch along with Donovan bodies on tissue smear is suggestive of granuloma inguinale.
  • Granuloma inguinale is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • Histological evaluation is essential for the diagnosis of donovanosis. Donovan bodies are seen within large, mononuclear (Pund) cells as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies.

choices.text: It is used only in males
It is used for genital ulcer

questions.text: True about grey kit used in syndromic management of STI
questions.solution:
• Grey kit

Kit 1

Uses: urethritis/ ano rectal discharge/ cervical discharge

Can be given either to male or female

Contents: tab 1azithromycin 1 gm stat

Tab 2: Cefixime 400mg stat

Reference: NACO guidelines for Syndromic Management of STI

questions.text: A patient presents with blistering skin lesions. To differentiate between pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus by cutaneous examination, which of the following would be the most helpful?
questions.solution:
Pemphigus vulgaris typically involves both skin and mucous membranes, with painful erosions commonly seen in the oral mucosa. In contrast, pemphigus foliaceus usually spares mucous membranes and involves only the superficial layers of the skin.

Therefore, the presence or absence of mucosal involvement is a key clinical differentiator between the two.

Explanation of other options:

Examination of palms and soles (Option B)

The palms and soles are typically not involved in either pemphigus vulgaris or pemphigus foliaceus. Involvement of these areas is more common in other conditions such as bullous pemphigoid, erythema multiforme, or hand-foot-mouth disease. Thus, this examination does not help in differentiating between the two pemphigus variants.

Examination of nails (Option C)

Nail involvement is not a characteristic feature of either pemphigus vulgaris or pemphigus foliaceus. While rare nail changes can occur in autoimmune blistering diseases, they are not specific enough to differentiate between these two conditions.

Wood's lamp examination of bullae (Option D)

Wood's lamp is used to detect fluorescence in conditions like tinea capitis, erythrasma, vitiligo, and porphyrias. The bullae seen in pemphigus vulgaris or foliaceus do not fluoresce under Wood's light. Therefore, this test has no diagnostic value in differentiating between the two.

questions.text: "Row of tombstones" appearance is characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
Histologically, pemphigus is characterized by loss of keratinocyte cell-cell adhesion, a process called acantholysis. In PV, acantholysis is present in the basal cell layer and the cells directly above it, forming a suprabasal blister.

Often the basal keratinocytes lose cell-cell (but not cell-basement membrane) adhesion and is called row of tombstones appearance.

In PF, acantholysis occurs in the upper epidermis, below the stratum corneum, within or immediately beneath the granular layer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with lesions in oral cavity as shown below. His proximal nail fold has extended onto the nail bed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mucosal involvement affects over half of all LP patients and frequently is the sole presenting sign.

It is most commonly seen in the mouth but can be found on the lips, esophagus, glans penis, vulva, or vagina.

Two main subtypes of oral LP exist: reticular, erosive

Reticular is the most common form and presents as asymptomatic white, lacy lines often seen on the bilateral buccal mucosa.

The erosive form is commonly associated with a burning pain exacerbated by hot or spicy foods. A very low risk (~1% of oral SCC).

questions.text: Which of the following is used as chemical peels in melasma
questions.solution:
Chemical peeling is the application of a chemical agent to the skin, which causes the controlled destruction of a part or of the entire epidermis, with or without the dermis, leading to exfoliation and removal of superficial lesions, followed by the regeneration of new epidermal and dermal tissues.

Chemical peels are a well-known modality of treatment for melasma. The basic mechanism of the action of chemical peels in melasma is the removal of unwanted melanin by causing a controlled chemical burn to the skin. Glycolic acid peel is the most commonly used alpha hydroxy peel.

Other peels - Salicylic acid(Beta hydroxy peels), Mandelic acid, trichloro acetic acid, Jessner's solution, Tretinoin peels

questions.text: A mason presents with these lesions on the hands as shown in the image. A patch test is done. Which of the following allergens is most likely to be positive ?
questions.solution:
The image shows a construction worker (mason) with erythematous, dry, and hyperkeratotic plaques predominantly over the palms. This pattern is strongly suggestive of occupational contact dermatitis, particularly due to repeated exposure to cement. The primary sensitizing agent in cement is potassium dichromate, a compound of hexavalent chromium. Upon skin contact, it acts as a hapten and induces a Type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Nickel (Option B): Nickel is a common allergen but is typically associated with jewelry and clothing accessories, not occupational exposure in masonry.

Cobalt (Option C): Though cobalt may be present in cement, it is a less frequent sensitizer compared to chromium.

Iron (Option D): Iron is not known to cause allergic contact dermatitis.

Key Takeaway:

Potassium dichromate (chromium) is the principal allergen responsible for allergic contact dermatitis in cement workers, especially masons.

choices.text: Mucosal involvement always follows the skin eruption
The Nikolsky sign is specific for Stevens-Johnson syndrome
The eruption typically begins on the lower limbs and spares palms and soles
A prodromal phase with systemic symptoms usually precedes the rash

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of fever, malaise, and a sore throat. He developed painful red macules and atypical targetoid lesions on his face and upper torso, which have now spread to involve his limbs and soles. He also complains of painful oral ulcers and difficulty swallowing. On examination, there is periungual dusky erythema and a positive Nikolsky sign. He had started allopurinol 12 days ago. Which of the following statements regarding his condition is most accurate?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), suggested by the prodrome of fever and malaise, painful mucocutaneous targetoid lesions with a positive Nikolsky sign, and recent allopurinol use. The most accurate statement is that a prodromal phase with systemic symptoms typically precedes the rash.

  • Latent period after drug initiation: 5-28 days, most often 7-10 days
  • Prodrome: Malaise, fever, URTI symptoms
  • Skin lesions begin as atypical targets/purpuric macules on the face and chest, spreading rapidly
  • Lesions may involve palms and soles and coalesce, forming blisters and flaccid bullae
  • Nikolsky sign is often positive but not specific
  • Mucosal involvement (oral, ocular, genital, respiratory, GI) may occur before, after, or with cutaneous lesions

Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN). Palmoplantar involvement. Multiple circular lesions are present on (a) the palms and (b) the soles. Blistering is occurring at both sites, but is prominent on the feet.

Explanation of other options:

Mucosal involvement always follows the skin eruption (Option A): Mucosal involvement can precede, follow, or occur simultaneously with the skin rash

The Nikolsky sign is specific for Stevens-Johnson syndrome (Option B): Nikolsky sign is not specific; also seen in pemphigus and other bullous diseases

The eruption typically begins on the lower limbs and spares palms and soles (Option C): The eruption typically starts on the face and chest, not lower limbs; palms and soles are often involved

questions.text: Black eschar over the back is due to which of the following
questions.solution:
Eschar is seen in-STAGE

S- Spider bite, Tick bite

T- Scrub typhus

A- Anthrax

GE- Ecthyma Gangrenosum

Scrub typhus:

Caused by bacteria called Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Scrub typhus is spread to people through bites of infected chiggers (larval mites).

Symptoms: Fever, headache, body aches, and sometimes rash.

Most cases of scrub typhus occur in rural areas of Southeast Asia, Indonesia, China, Japan, India, and northern Australia.

Treatment: Doxycycline

Cutaneous anthrax:

Caused by: Bacillus anthracis

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Types of scale

Collarette scale

Describes the fine, peripherally attached and centrally detached scale at the edge of salmon-colored patch/plaque. Examples: Pityriasis rosea, subsiding lesions of furuncle, miliaria, erythema nodosum, etc.

Branny/ Furfuraceous scale (Latin furfur - bran)

Describes fine and loose scales that are not conspicuous and made visible by scratching (scratch sign). Example: Pityriasis versicolor.

Micaceous scale (Silvery)

Describes a silvery, white, parakeratotic, lamellated scale. Silvery white appearance is due to reflection of light at the air-keratin interface between the layers of scale. Example: Psoriasis vulgaris.

Mica like scales are seen in Pityriasis lichenoid chronica

Greasy scale

Describes loose, moist, yellow-brown oily scaling, especially perifollicular, on seborrheic areas. Example: Seborrheic dermatitis.

Trailing scale

Describes annular erythema with advancing flat or elevated border and trailing scale at the inner border with central area flattening and fading. Lesions occur on the trunk and especially, buttocks, inner thighs. Example: Erythema annulare centrifugum.

Wafer like scale

Thin adherent mica-like scale attached at the center of a lichenoid firm reddish brown papule and free at the periphery. Example: Pityriasis lichenoides chronica. In clear cell acanthoma, wafer-like scale is seen adherent at the periphery, which leaves a moist or bleeding surface when removed.

Double-edged scale

Describes erythematous, exfoliating or scaly, annular or polycyclic, flat patch with an incomplete advancing double edge of peeling scale. Example: Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa (ILC). [Netherton syndrome=ILC + hair abnormality + atopic diathesis]

Cornflake sign/scale Sometimes used for scale crust of pemphigus foliaceus. Cornflake sign seen in Flegel′s disease is characterized by 2-3 mm keratotic scaly papules with discrete irregular margins. The scale separates from many lesions, leaving a non-exudative red base.

Oyster-like scale

Large heaped-up scale accumulation in psoriasis is described as ostraceous or oyster-like scale.

choices.text: 50% cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure without any treatment
Spontaneous remission less in children than adults
Indeterminate leprosy resolves more spontaneously than tuberculoid leprosy
Leprosy heals by itself in most of the patients in 1 year

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about leprosy, if leprosy is untreated
questions.solution:
95% cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure without any treatment (Thus option A is incorrect)

Spontaneous remission more in children than adults (option B is incorrect)

Indeterminate leprosy resolves more spontaneously than tuberculoid leprosy (Option C is correct)

Multibacillary leprosy with high bacillary load may not heal in 1 year. (Thus option D is incorrect)

questions.text: Male child born to a non consanguineous couple presents with blisters on the face associated with friction. H/O similar presentation in a previous child who died 2 weeks after birth. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case is genetic disorder (because present in family), erosion and blisters over trauma prone sites suggests diagnosis towards mechano-bullous disorder.

Epidermolysis bullosa is mechanobullous disorder.


CHRONIC BULLOUS DISEASE OF CHILDHOOD

CBDC is an immunobullous disease characterized by the presence of tense bullae and the linear deposition of IgA at the dermal-epidermal junction of lesional and perilesional skin.

The clinical hallmark of this condition is the abrupt appearance on normal or erythematous skin of many large, tense bullae, filled with clear or sometimes hemorrhagic fluid and acquiring the typical rosette-like pattern of 'string of pearls'.

Congenital syphilis

A rare bullous variant, known as syphilitic pemphigus, most commonly occurs on palms and soles. Vesicles might be present at birth or occur in the first week of life, and the serous content contain abundant treponemes

VDRL titre should be 4 times more than VDRL of mother.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting hair?
questions.solution:
This picture shows polarizing microscopy of hair with 'tiger tail band' appearance, seen in trichothiodystrophy.

Trichothiodystrophy

It is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Abnormal synthesis of sulfur containing amino acid leads to deficiency of cysteine and methionine. Thus, hairs are rough and fragile resulting in Tiger tail appearance.

Clinically patient presents with diffuse sparseness and broken hair all over the scalp since childhood.

It can be associated with_

PIBIDS

P- Photosensitivity

I- Ichthyosis

B- Brittle hair

I- Intellectual impairment

D- Decreased fertility

S- Short stature

Trichorrhexis invaginata


It is a hair shaft disorder.

Hair shaft telescopes into itself along the shaft (Invaganation) "Ball and Socket" appearance

Trichorrhexis invaginata is pathognomonic of Netherton syndrome

Netherton syndrome consists triad of

  • Atopic dermatitis
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata
  • Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa (Double edged scales)

Trichorrhexis nodosa


It is a hair shaft defect with nodes in hair shaft

Monilethrix


It is a hair shaft defect with beaded appearance in hair shaft

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• Epidermoid cyst, also known as a sebaceous cyst, is a benign encapsulated, subepidermal nodule filled with keratin material.
  • Although most commonly located on the face, neck, and trunk, epidermoid cysts can be found anywhere including the scrotum, genitalia, fingers, and cases within the buccal mucosa.
  • Cysts may progress slowly and remain present for years.
  • The term sebaceous cyst is commonly used; however, the term is a misnomer in that it does not involve the sebaceous gland.
  • Epidermoid cysts develop within the infundibulum. cysts can be found in autosomal dominant (AD) Gardner syndrome (familial adenomatous polyposis) and Gorlin syndrome (basal cell nevus syndrome).

questions.text: A truck driver presented with complains of painless genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. The motility of the causative organism can be best checked by which microscope ?
questions.solution:
• painless irregular ulcers and inguinal swelling - point towards case of syphilis
  • Syphilis is a bacterial infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.
  • Primary syphilis appears 10 to 90 days after exposure to the infection and comprises a painless, indurated ulcer (chancre) at the site of inoculation with the T. pallidum.
  • Regional lymphadenopathy is common and consists of rubbery lymph nodes.
  • The chancre oozes serum, which is teeming with treponema
  • In this case next best step, would be to do dark field microscopy
  • Darkfield examination by microscope allows for direct examination of spirochetes from the mucosal lesion and thus offers an immediate diagnosis if positive
  • Test to rule out other STI should be done if feasible .
  • Inj Benzathine penicillin 2.4 mIU is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A HIV positive adult male presented with hilar lymphadenopathy and lung involvement presented with lesions on face as shown. CBNAAT was negative. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
HISTOPLASMOSIS:

  • Histoplasmosis is caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, and it is endemic in certain areas, especially in regions with high bat or bird droppings.

Mode of infection: Inhalation of mycelial fragments of the fungus.

  • In immunocompromised individuals, like those with HIV, histoplasmosis can disseminate beyond the lungs, causing widespread disease.
  • Pulmonary symptoms (such as lung involvement and hilar lymphadenopathy) are common, and skin lesions can occur in disseminated forms with polymorphic lesion.
  • A negative CBNAAT (a test for tuberculosis) is common since histoplasmosis is a fungal infection, not bacterial. It can mimic tuberculosis in clinical presentation, especially in HIV patients.

questions.text: Patient with orange scaly skin, palmoplantar keratoderma, keratotic follicular papules on hands and histopathology showing alternating ortho-parakeratosis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of orange scaly skin, palmoplantar keratoderma, keratotic follicular papules on hands, and histopathological findings showing alternating ortho-parakeratosis strongly suggests a diagnosis of pityriasis rubra pilaris.

Diagnosis

Diagnosis: Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Supporting Information

Clinical Features: Pityriasis rubra pilaris typically presents with well-defined, orange-red scaling plaques that can be associated with palmoplantar keratoderma. The follicular papules are a characteristic feature, often seen on the extensor surfaces.

Histopathology: The presence of alternating ortho-parakeratosis is a notable histological finding in pityriasis rubra pilaris, differentiating it from other similar conditions like psoriasis, which usually shows more extensive parakeratosis and neutrophilic infiltration.

Response to Treatment: Patients with pityriasis rubra pilaris may respond to various treatments, including retinoids and phototherapy, which further supports this diagnosis.

Given these considerations, the correct answer to your question is:

  1. Pityriasis rubra pilaris

questions.text: A patient presented witrh acne on face and body. Which is the most effective treatment for the condition?
questions.solution:
The most effective treatment for a patient presenting with acne on the face and body is:

Correct Answer

b. Systemic isotretinoin

Supporting Information

Isotretinoin: This medication is a powerful retinoid that targets multiple factors contributing to acne, including excess sebum production, clogged pores, bacterial growth, and inflammation. It is particularly effective for severe cases of acne that have not responded to other treatments.

Effectiveness: Studies indicate that isotretinoin leads to significant improvement in acne severity, with about 85% of patients experiencing permanent clearing after one course of treatment. It is often considered the gold standard for treating severe or resistant acne.

Other Options:

Systemic doxycycline and minocycline (options a and c) are antibiotics that can help reduce inflammation and bacterial load but are generally less effective than isotretinoin for severe cases.

Dapsone (option d) is primarily used for inflammatory acne but is not as effective as isotretinoin for widespread or severe acne.

choices.text: Caused by both Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the disease shown below is true?
questions.solution:
• Bullous impetigo produces subcorneal (intraepidermal) bullae due to exfoliative toxin A cleaving desmoglein-1 in the superficial epidermis.
  • The toxin causes loss of cell adhesion between keratinocytes, leading to flaccid bullae with purulent fluid collected in the lower half (hypopyon sign).
  • After rupture, thin, flat crusts are formed.
  • Predominantly affects infants and children <2 years
  • If the toxin disseminates, there is a risk of Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) in vulnerable patients.

Explanation of other options:

  • Regional lymphadenopathy (Option B) is uncommon in bullous impetigo; systemic signs are typically minimal.
  • Honey-colored crusts (Option C)characterise non-bullous impetigo; bullous impetigo initially presents with larger, fluid-filled bullae.
  • Bullous impetigo is caused almost exclusively by Staph. Aureus - not by Strep. pyogenes.(Option D)
